document.docAuthor: Tang, Pu, Achterberg, Cornelis Van & Chen, Xue-Xin
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the genus Earinus Wesmael (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Agathidinae) from China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the genus Earinus Wesmael (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Agathidinae) from China

heading.emphasis:
Key to Chinese species of the genus
Earinus Wesmael

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Head and mesosoma conspicuously long setose ( Fig. 3G ); face strongly and conspicuously punctate and laterally flattened compared to middle ( Fig. 3B ); hind tibia yellowish brown, but subbasally paler than apically ( Fig. 3F ). China ( Heilongjiang , Jilin ); Europe; Turkey ; Far East Russia , Japan ...................................................................................
E. elator ( Fabricius, 1804 )

- Head and mesosoma normally setose ( Figs 1G , 2B , 4H , 5F , 6F , 7F ); face at most punctulate and laterally weakly convex ( Figs 1C , 2F , 4E , 5G , 6G , 7B ); hind tibia (except apical third) largely or completely pale or whitish yellow or entirely dark brown or black (
Figs 1I
, 7E ) ........................................................................................................................................................................ 2

2. Ovipositor sheath 0.3–0.5 × fore wing (= 0.25–0.45 × body and 0.5–0.8 × metasoma) ( Figs 2A , 4A ); third metasomal tergite without medial elevation ( Figs 2H , 4G ); basal half of ovipositor sheath largely narrow ( Figs 2A , 4A ); hind tibia pale yellowish subbasally or entirely black ( Figs 2A , 4A ).................................................................................................................................. 3

- Ovipositor sheath 0.9–1.3 × fore wing (= 0.8–1.4 × body and 1.4–2.6 × metasoma) ( Figs 5A , 6A , 7A ); third metasomal tergite with medial elevation ( Figs 1F , 5D ,
6I
); basal half of ovipositor sheath largely ribbon-shaped ( Figs 5A , 6A , 7A ); hind tibia with dark brown or brown dorsal spot subbasally (
Figs 1I
, 5A , 6A , 7E )............................................................................................. 5

- Length of malar space 2.6-2.7 × basal width of mandible; POL 0.7 × OOL; length of first metasomal tergite 1.3 ×its apical width; fore leg almost entirely black; first tergite smooth. China ( Taiwan , Fujian?)..............
E. bicolor Chou et Sharkey, 1989

5. Hind femur comparatively short and less slender (
Figs 1I
, 6H ); first metasomal tergite robust ( Figs 1F ,
6I
); colour of hind tibial spurs similar to colour of middle of hind basitarsus (
Fig. 1I
) ..................................................................................................... 6

- Hind femur comparatively long and slender ( Figs 5H , 7E ); first tergite less robust ( Fig. 5D ); relative colour of hind tibial spurs and middle of basitarsus variable ( Figs 5A , 7E ) .......................................................................................................................... 7

6. Mandible yellowish or brown ( Fig. 1C ); area of second tergite truncate medio-posteriorly ( Fig. 1F ); hind tibial spurs dark brown (
Fig. 1I
).
China ( Tibet , Fuzhou?, Yunnan ?, Taiwan ?)
; Vietnam ; Thailand .
E. aurantius van Achterberg et Long, 2010

- Mandible black ( Fig. 6G ); area of second tergite protruding medio-posteriorly (
Fig. 6I
); hind tibial spurs yellowish brown ( Fig. 6A ). China ( Sichuan , Zhejiang ).....................................................................................................................
E. protinus
sp. nov.

7. Mandible brown (but basally darker) ( Fig. 7B ); scapus gradually curved dorsally; hind basitarsus largely dark brown, middle similar to hind spurs ( Fig. 7E ). China ( Guizhou , Fujian )........................................................
E. wuyiensis Chen et Yang, 1999

- Mandible black ( Fig. 5G ); scapus angularly curved dorsally; hind basitarsus pale yellowish, middle paler than hind spurs ( Fig. 5A ). China ( Tibet ) .......................................................................................................................................
E. pallitarsus
sp. nov.
